subject: US President Trump says US is continuing to see encouraging signs of progress and that all parts of the US are in good shape or getting better, adds there is hunger for getting our country back to work
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE / RESPONSES

US President Trump questioned why should taxpayers be bailing out poorly run states (like Illinois, as example) in which he suggested all cases were Democrat run and managed, while he added that most of the other states are not looking for bailout help. (Twitter)

Texas Governor said the state-wide stay-at-home order will expire on April 30th and will not be renewed, while they will reopen businesses in phases beginning on May 1st and more in two weeks if the infection rates are tame. Furthermore, the Governor added that retail stores, bars and restaurants will be reopened on May 1st but at a 25% occupancy limit. (Newswires)

Banks are said to expect the next round of PPP stimulus loans to run out in days, while financial firms and brokers are still applying for money, according to FBN's Gasparino. (Twitter)

UK COVID-19 death toll rose to 21,092 (prev. 20,732) which is an increase of 360 (+1.72%) vs. yesterday's increase of 413 (+2.03%) and represents the slowest daily increase since March 30th. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson said we are making progress on COVID-19 and we are passing through the peak, while he added we are on the brink of achieving the first clear mission in preventing the NHS being overwhelmed and are beginning to turn the tide. However, PM Johnson added this is the moment of maximum risk and he sees the consequences of the lockdown but must recognise the risk of a second spike and allowing the R0 to move above 1, while he stated we are approaching the end of phase 1 and when we are sure the first phase is over, that will be the time to move on but cannot determine when such changes will be made and will say more in the coming days. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson spokesman said we are coming through the peak and will set out more information on meeting the five lockdown tests in due course. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

US proposed new restrictions on certain exports to China due to national security with new restrictions involving exports to military buyers in China. (Newswires)

India is said to be considering USD 39bln in new small-business loans. (Newswires)

Westpac sees the RBNZ to lower the OCR into negative territory of -0.5% later this year from current 0.25%, while it noted that there is large stimulus already being delivered through QE and government’s economic packages but anticipates further action will be required later in the year. (Westpac) 

 

UK/EU

UK Chancellor Sunak said the government will guarantee 100% of small business loans which will not be tested against future liabilities and with interest paid for first 12-months. (Newswires)

UK Cabinet Office Minister Gove said it is possible to complete Brexit negotiations within the deadline and that the text for talks between the EU and UK will be published within a matter of weeks. (Newswires)

Bank of England said in the current circumstances, it will be challenging for many businesses to provide forecasts for financials with a high degree of confidence to support the loan underwriting process. (Newswires)

European Commission is to temporarily ease rules on leverage ratio calculation to help banks lend more in pandemic and is to propose allowing banks to opt into relief from the bad loan provisioning rule, according to sources. (Newswires)

 

US

Fed expanded scope and duration of municipal liquidity facility and increased the duration of eligible securities to 3 years from 2 years, while it stated that it will consider expanding facility to include limited number of government entities that issue revenue bonds. Furthermore, it noted that it is to lend as much as USD 500bln under the facility on USD 35bln of Treasury equity and that the changes will permit substantially more entities to borrow. (Newswires)

White House Advisor Hassett said the US economy will not see a V-shaped recovery without another stimulus bill. Furthermore, he earlier stated that Q2 GDP will be the largest negative number since the great depression and likely between -20 to -30%, although Q3 will likely be positive. (Newswires)

US Senate Republican Leader McConnell said there probably will be another bill for funding state and local governments, while he suggested that the "red line" for next aid bill would be liability protections. There were also comments from House Majority Leader Hoyer that the House will be in session next week from Monday and that votes are possible. (Newswires) 

 

MARKET RECAP

Risk has started the week on the front foot, with desks citing easing of lockdown restrictions on the horizon as the supporting factor. The BOJ lifted restrictions on bond-buying overnight, allowing it to theoretically buy unlimited amounts of government bonds to achieve its YCC targets; there will be attention on the Fed and ECB meetings later in the week (Weds and Thurs, respectively). Additionally, mega tech companies MSFT, AAPl, GOOG, AMZN and FB will be reporting numbers this week; collectively, they represent around 21% of the SPX market cap. Morgan Stanley highlight the growing market concentration of the top five market cap companies in the SPX (currently MSFT, AAPL, AMZN, FB, GOOGL) which since 2016, has grown from just above 10% to just below 20% - a level not seen since the 1970’s Nifty Fifty era. Apple (AAPL) is reportedly delaying its 2020 iPhone production ramp-up by approximately one month, although it still plans to release four new iPhones later in the year and is looking to slash H2 production by up to 20%, according to WSJ citing sources. Boeing Company (BA) announced it has terminated the JV agreement with Embraer (ERJ), who believes the termination was wrongfully terminated and made false claims. Meanwhile, two influential proxy advisory firms have recommended that BA shareholders vote against key board members to protest how it handled the 737 MAX crisis, according to WSJ, however, all 12 directors received majority shareholder votes. SPX +1.5% at 2878, NDX +0.6% at 8838, DJIA +1.5% at 34,134.

The Treasury curve bear-steepened on Wednesday, amid a constructive risk backdrop which was supported by optimism on the easing of lockdown restrictions. Action was light ahead of key risk events this week (Fed, ECB, key corporate earnings). The BOJ overnight effectively announced unlimited QE, which was also said to be supporting risk in APAC trade. Additionally, there was talk of desks selling to make way for supply. Although the FOMC meeting this week is only expected to “take stock” of the situation, with no major announcement expected, desks will, however, be keeping an eye on any commentary regarding Japanese/Australian-style YCC on the horizon. The US Treasury sold both 2-year and 5-year notes today - both solid auctions that stopped-through the screens on decent demand. Starting with the former, which was sold at 0.229% (from the prior 0.39%), stopping-through by a chunky 1.3bps - the largest amount since July 2012; cover was 3.1x, the highest since January 2018. Direct participation was in line with recent averages, and indirects took a higher share than recent sales, leaving dealers with the lowest since last November. The 5s auction was similar, but to a lesser extent, stopping through by 0.7bps.  Both auctions highlight that, despite projections of the US deficit rising to above USD 3trln in 2020, demand is still strong for shorter-dated Treasuries; some have suggested that this is as the market eyes potential yield curve control from the Fed, which isn’t likely to be a feature of Wednesday’s confab, though will be a key issue into the June FOMC, where some believe that the Fed might pledge to leave rates at the effective lower bound for a couple of years, supported by its action in controlling short-term yields. T-notes (M0) settled 14+ ticks lower at 138-21.

Newsquawk US Market Wrap - April 27th: Stocks higher as recovery prospects improve
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, Dollar down, Crude down.
  • REARVIEW: BoJ removes limit on government bond purchases, Storage concerns continue to hit crude nearby futures, solid US auctions as traders take advantage of higher yields
  • COMING UP: Data: Japanese Unemployment, US Consumer Confidence. Event: Riksbank Rate Decision. Supply: UK & US. Earnings: BP, HSBC, Alphabet, Merck, Pfizer, AMD, Caterpillar

MARKET WRAP

Risk has started the week on the front foot, with desks citing easing of lockdown restrictions on the horizon as the supporting factor. The BOJ lifted restrictions on bond-buying overnight, allowing it to theoretically buy unlimited amounts of government bonds to achieve its YCC targets; there will be attention on the Fed and ECB meetings later in the week (Weds and Thurs, respectively). Additionally, mega tech companies MSFT, AAPl, GOOG, AMZN and FB will be reporting numbers this week; collectively, they represent around 21% of the SPX market cap. Results from Gilead’s (GILD) remdesivir in a US trial on severe COVID-19 patients is due in the coming days, which will likely nudge markets depending on the tone of the results if the other recent updates are anything to go by.

VIRUS CASE COUNT

Figures provided as of Monday (via state official health departments) against weekend:

  • US: Cases +3.15% at 957,875 (prev. 928,619); death toll +2.8% at 53,922 (Prev. 52,459)
  • NEW YORK: cases +1.4% at 291,996 (prev. +2.1% at 288,045); death toll rises 2% to 17,303 (prev. +2.2% at 16,966); Cuomo says they will extend the stay at home order beyond May 15th in many parts of the state
  • ITALY: Cases rise 0.9% to 199,414 (prev. +1.2% at 197,675), death toll rises 1.3% to 26,077 (prev. +1.0% at 26,644). Italy to ease lockdown restrictions from May 4th.
  • UK: Cases rise to 157,149 (prev. 152,840), death toll rises to 21,092 (prev. 20,732); deaths rise by 300 (+1.74%) vs. yesterday's increase of 413 (+2.03%)
  • CANADA: Cases at 47,327 (prev. 45,791); death toll 2,617 (prev. 2,489)

NORTH AMERICA

COVID FOCUS: The White House plans to shift its coronavirus messaging toward boosting the economy and highlighting “success stories” of businesses, reducing its public emphasis on health statistics, sources cited by Axios said on Sunday. But markets will still be paying attention to some health statistics, of course, particularly on reinfections. An analysis by the FT suggests that the global death toll could be 60% higher than reported, with mortality statistics showing 122k deaths in excess of normal levels across 14 countries, considerably higher the FT says than the 77k official Covid-19 deaths reported for the same places and time periods.

US STIMULUS v4.0: US President Trump’s Economic Adviser Hassett said Q2 GDP will be the largest negative number since the Great Depression, likely seeing a contraction in the magnitude of 20-30%, though he believes Q3 will likely be positive. Hassett called on lawmakers to enact further stimulus, warning that without it, there would not be a V-shaped recovery. Markets now have expectations that the fourth tranche of stimulus will be focusing on relief for States and local governments, infrastructure spending, and additionally, support for US energy companies feeling the strain under the collapse of global crude prices. Elsewhere, Fox News reported that US banks expect the next round of PPP pandemic stimulus loans to run out within days; last week, some desks had suggested that this could be taken as a sign that the funds are filtering through to the real economy quickly. Meanwhile, House Speaker Pelosi said Democrats will press for oversight of COVID-19 relief packages. Note, Senate Majority Leader McConnell announced the Senate will return on May 4th although there will be a modified routine. The return of the senate could perhaps speed up the process of the next round of stimulus.

CENTRAL BANKS

BOJ: The key interest rate was left unchanged at -0.1% and forward guidance tweaked in which the reference to price momentum was dropped - as touted by sources last week. The Bank reaffirmed its pledge to further ease without hesitation if necessary, whilst Governor Kuroda did not rule out deeper negative rates as a future option but said it's hard to see rates declining. The Bank of Japan removed its JPY 80trln limit on buying government bonds, and can now buy an unlimited amount of government bonds to meet its objective to keep 10-year yields around zero; the move comes at a time when the government will be boosting debt issuance to finance its COVID-19 response. The BOJ said it would buy JGBs and short-term securities "actively" to keep markets stable. It also increased the scale of buying commercial paper and corporate debt (almost trebling from JPY 7.4trln to JPY 20trln/year). Its forecasts saw the central bank cut its forecasts and projected that it will miss its 2% inflation goal for three more years. Elsewhere, the bank broadened accepted collateral in its operations. Citi's analysts do not think the announcement has much material impact for financial market players, and the bank explains: 1) the Fed has already announced unlimited bond purchases effectively and has been enacting this; 2) the BOJ has decreased JGB purchases remarkably since 2017; purchased amounts, which totalled close to JPY 80trln in 2016, decreased to only JPY 15trln last year, and its annualised size has grown only to JPY 30trln since this February when purchases reaccelerated; 3) under the current YCC framework, asset purchases play only a secondary role.

CRUDE

WTI (M0) SETTLES USD 4.16 LOWER AT USD 12.78/BBL, WTI (N0) SETTLES USD 3.14 LOWER AT 18.08/BBL; BRENT (M0) SETTLES USD 1.45 LOWER AT USD 19.99/BBL, BRENT (N0) SETTLES USD 1.74 LOWER AT USD 23.07/BBL

Another session of chunky losses for crude futures, albeit off the lows, again led by the nearby contracts as storage concerns linger and participants move further out the crude term structure. The June WTI futures were particularly hit after the USO fund announced that between today and month-end, it would withdraw any exposure to the June contract, and increase exposure further down the curve and even into 2021. Elsewhere, the DoE announced that the SPR had seen stocks build by 1.1mln bbls over the week ending April 24th – a somewhat expected update, but given recent builds (e.g. +20mln in US weekly crude stocks), the 1.1mln will have little balancing effect. Participants looking for a more stable oil market in the coming weeks will likely be disappointed, Goldman Sachs warns, “commodities are spot assets, not anticipatory assets and must clear current supply and demand, which still remain extremely out of balance in all markets.” The bank caveats that the market is now at an inflection phase with rebalancing having commenced, although could take between eight-to-twelve weeks before it believes it can confidently argue that a bottom has been made.

FIXED INCOME

T-NOTES (M0) SETTLED 14+ TICKS LOWER AT 138-21.

The Treasury curve bear-steepened on Wednesday, amid a constructive risk backdrop which was supported by optimism on the easing of lockdown restrictions. Action was light ahead of key risk events this week (Fed, ECB, key corporate earnings). The BOJ overnight effectively announced unlimited QE, which was also said to be supporting risk in APAC trade. Additionally, there was talk of desks selling to make way for supply. Although the FOMC meeting this week is only expected to “take stock” of the situation, with no major announcement expected, desks will, however, be keeping an eye on any commentary regarding Japanese/Australian-style YCC on the horizon.

AUCTIONS: The US Treasury sold both 2-year and 5-year notes today - both solid auctions that stopped-through the screens on decent demand. Starting with the former, which was sold at 0.229% (from the prior 0.39%), stopping-through by a chunky 1.3bps - the largest amount since July 2012; cover was 3.1x, the highest since January 2018. Direct participation was in line with recent averages, and indirects took a higher share than recent sales, leaving dealers with the lowest since last November. The 5s auction was similar, but to a lesser extent, stopping through by 0.7bps.  Both auctions highlight that, despite projections of the US deficit rising to above USD 3trln in 2020, demand is still strong for shorter-dated Treasuries; some have suggested that this is as the market eyes potential yield curve control from the Fed, which isn’t likely to be a feature of Wednesday’s confab, though will be a key issue into the June FOMC, where some believe that the Fed might pledge to leave rates at the effective lower bound for a couple of years, supported by its action in controlling short-term yields.

EQUITIES

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +1.5% at 2878, NDX +0.6% at 8838, DJIA +1.5% at 34,134.

SECTORS: Financials +3.6%, Real Estate +3%, Materials +2.6%, Industrials +2.5%, Energy +2.1%, Health Care +1.3%, Communications +1.3%, Consumer Discretionary +1.2%, Utilities +1.1%, IT +0.9%, Consumer Staples +0.3%

STOCK SPECIFICS: Morgan Stanley highlight the growing market concentration of the top five market cap companies in the SPX (currently MSFT, AAPL, AMZN, FB, GOOGL) which since 2016, has grown from just above 10% to just below 20% - a level not seen since the 1970’s Nifty Fifty era. Apple (AAPL) is reportedly delaying its 2020 iPhone production ramp-up by approximately one month, although it still plans to release four new iPhones later in the year and is looking to slash H2 production by up to 20%, according to WSJ citing sources. Boeing Company (BA) announced it has terminated the JV agreement with Embraer (ERJ), who believes the termination was wrongfully terminated and made false claims. Meanwhile, two influential proxy advisory firms have recommended that BA shareholders vote against key board members to protest how it handled the 737 MAX crisis, according to WSJ, however, all 12 directors received majority shareholder votes. BA CEO announced the jet manufacturer will have to borrow more money over the next six months, adding it will be years before it begins paying dividends again. Diamond Offshore (DO) filed for its Chapter 11 bankruptcy, weighing on Lowe’s (L) who own a majority stake in the co. and will face a USD 1.5bln loss from the bankruptcy. General Motors (GM) announced it has extended USD 3.6bln under its revolving credit facility to April 2022, while suspending its quarterly cash dividend and share repurchase programme. Of note for some cloud names, Alphabet Google (GOOG) is reportedly in talks to acquire cloud company D2iQ, according to Axios citing sources familiar with the matter. Expectations are that D2iQ would be valued over USD 250mln it raised from Venture Capitalists, although less than the USD 775mln valuation it received.

EARNINGS: As of Friday night (04/24/20), Credit Suisse highlight that 28.2% of the S&P 500's market cap has reported 1Q results. Although earnings are missing estimates in aggregate by -3.4%, ex-Financials earnings are surpassing expectations by 6.3%, with 72% of companies exceeding their lowered projections. Note, the top 5 weighted SPX companies (MSFT, AAPL, AMZN, FB, GOOGL) are all scheduled to report this week. 

FOREX

USD: With sentiment improving amid global reopening updates (NY could be as early as May 15th, Italy May 4th), the dollar has sold off some of its gains and the DXY now trades beneath 100. Elsewhere, with month-end approaching, Barclay's month-end rebalancing model points to moderate USD selling.

JPY: The yen was firmer to start the week despite improved risk sentiment while the BoJ announced unlimited QE to assist with yield curve control, while it also announced it would increase purchases of corporate bonds and dropped its reference to price momentum in its forward guidance, in line with source reports last week.  Despite the easing, albeit expected, and improved risk sentiment USDJPY fell to lows of 107.00 with analysts highlighting 106.93 as a key support level. Today’s option expiries also likely had an impact with USD 1.2bln rolling off at the 107 figure.

EUR: The single currency is flat against the greenback at pixel time although it had been firmer in the morning after S&P left Italy’s rating unchanged at BBB; outlook negative, while many had expected a downgrade. Also reassuring is Italy’s plans to exit lockdown on May 4th will also support sentiment as any re-opening or vaccine updates seem to be the current market drivers. Focus this week on the Euro will be with the ECB on Wednesday, with many eyeing any potential updates to its PEPP.

AUD/NZD: Cyclical currencies performed well today amid the improved risk sentiment with the Aussie the G10 outperformer amid the announcement Queensland will relax restrictions from May 1st and parts in the West will be able to hold gatherings of up to 10 people. Analysts at Citi highlight their bullish case for the currency noting the large fiscal package, low capita cases of COVID-19 which has led to lighter lockdown measures and the close ties with Asian economies which are expected to recover faster given the earlier exposure to COVID-19.  NZD also performing well and traded above 0.60 throughout the day with the country set to re-open tomorrow.

GBP: Sterling firmer in line with its cyclical counterparts amid the improved risk sentiment while gains could also be attributed to the return of Boris Johnson in power after recovering from the coronavirus. Cable had reclaimed 1.24 to the upside, a level it resides around at pixel time, after seeing highs at 1.2450, technical analysts at Credit Suisse look for resistance in the cross at the 55-day average resistance at 1.2526.

CAD: Despite the fallout in oil prices today, the loony was resilient perhaps trading off risk rather than oil today with USDCAD back beneath 1.41. Scotia highlight the moves in equities with Vix beneath 40 are encouraging for CAD. The desk writes “We expect the CAD will continue to move to the beat of risk appetite to a large extent but weak crude prices—which are likely to persist for some weeks at least—will limit scope for gains.”

EMFX was mixed today amid improved risk sentiment and falling oil prices. RUB was weaker amid the declining oil prices with Brent (M0) trading sub USD 20/bbl and WTI (M0) seeing lows beneath USD 12/bbl. However, RUB was only slightly weaker against a falling buck. Elsewhere, MXN & ZAR both firmer amid improved risk sentiment, while BRL underperforms.

BRL: A senior public prosecutor has requested the authority to investigate allegations of political interference by President Bolsonaro, the BBC reported. It follows last week's resignation of Justice Minister Moro, who accused Bolsonaro of trying to install a new federal police chief who would provide him with intelligence reports. Bolsonaro has denied the reports, although it throws an unwelcome distraction into the mix as the country tries to battle COVID.

FX WRAP: USD tumbles as risk sentiment improves, supporting cyclicals
content:
USD: With sentiment improving amid global reopening updates (NY could be as early as May 15th, Italy May 4th), the dollar has sold off some of its gains and the DXY now trades beneath 100. Elsewhere, with month end approaching, Barclays month end rebalancing model points to moderate USD selling.

JPY: The yen was firmer to start the week despite improved risk sentiment while the BoJ announced unlimited QE to assist with yield curve control, while it also announced it would increase purchases of corporate bonds and dropped its reference to price momentum in its forward guidance, in line with source reports last week. Despite the easing, albeit expected, and improved risk sentiment USDJPY fell to lows of 107.00 with analysts highlighting 106.93 as a key support level. Today’s option expiries also likely had an impact with USD 1.2bln rolling off at the 107 figure.

EUR: The single currency is flat against the greenback at pixel time although it had been firmer in the morning after S&P left Italy’s rating unchanged at BBB; outlook negative, while many had expected a downgrade. Also reassuring, is Italy’s plans to exit lockdown on May 4th will also support sentiment as any re-opening or vaccine updates seem to be the current market drivers. Focus this week on the Euro will be with the ECB on Wednesday, with many eyeing any potential updates to its PEPP.

AUD/NZD: Cyclical currencies performed well today amid the improved risk sentiment with the Aussie the G10 outperformer amid the announcement Queensland will relax restrictions from May 1st and parts in the West will be able to hold gatherings of up to 10 people. Analysts at Citi highlight their bullish case for the currency noting the large fiscal package, low capita cases of COVID-19 which has led to lighter lockdown measures and the close ties with Asian economies which are expected to recover faster given the earlier exposure to COVID-19. NZD also performing well and traded above 0.60 throughout the day with the country set to re-open tomorrow.

GBP: Sterling firmer in line with its cyclical counterparts amid the improved risk sentiment while gains could also be attributed to the return of Boris Johnson in power after recovering from the coronavirus. Cable had reclaimed 1.24 to the upside, a level it resides around at pixel time, after seeing highs at 1.2450, technical analysts at Credit Suisse look for resistance in the cross at the 55-day average resistance at 1.2526.

CAD: Despite the fallout in oil prices today, the loony was resilient perhaps trading off risk rather than oil today with USDCAD back beneath 1.41. Scotia highlight the moves in equities with vix beneath 40 are encouraging for CAD. The desk writes “We expect the CAD will continue to move to the beat of risk appetite to a large extent but weak crude prices—which are likely to persist for some weeks at least—will limit scope for gains.”

EMFX was mixed today amid improved risk sentiment and falling oil prices. RUB was weaker amid the declining oil prices with Brent (M0) trading sub USD 20/bbl and WTI (M0) seeing lows beneath USD 12/bbl. However, RUB was only slightly weaker against a falling buck. Elsewhere, MXN & ZAR both firmer amid improved risk sentiment, while BRL underperforms.

BRL: A senior public prosecutor has requested the authority to investigate allegations of political interference by President Bolsonaro, the BBC reported. It follows last week's resignation of Justice Minister Moro, who accussed Bolsonaro of trying to install a new federal police chief who would provide him with intelligence reports. Bolsonaro has denied the reports, although it throws an unwelcome distraction into the mix as the country tries to battle COVID.

ZAR: Trading more in line with risk sentiment than domestic drivers. Over the weekend, Treasury official confirmed the country is seeking USD 5bln in loans from the IMF/World Bank/New Development Bank.

TRY: The Lira is weaker against the buck, with desks citing remarks from a health ministry official who said the true number of infections in the country was likely higher than the reported official figures implied. However, Lira losses may be limited by the fall in oil prices.

MXN: Although there are no firm timelines, Mexico will apparently re-open auto factories in line with the US and Canada. MXN trades firmer today in line with risk sentiment, largely ignoring the decline in crude prices today.

subject: T-NOTES (M0) SETTLED 14+ TICKS LOWER AT 138-21.
analysis_details:
TREASURIES: The Treasury curve bear-steepened on Wednesday, amid a constructive risk backdrop which was supported by optimism on the easing of lockdown restrictions. Action was light ahead of key risk events this week (Fed, ECB, key corporate earnings). The BOJ overnight effectively announced unlimited QE, which was also said to be supporting risk in APAC trade. Additionally, there was talk of desks selling to make way for supply. Although the FOMC meeting this week is only expected to “take stock” of the situation, with no major announcement expected, desks will however be keeping an eye on any commentary regarding Japanese/Australian-style YCC on the horizon.   

AUCTIONS: The US Treasury sold both 2-year and 5-year notes today - both solid auctions that stopped-through the screens on decent demand. Starting with the former, which was sold at 0.229% (from the prior 0.39%), stopping-through by a chunky 1.3bps - the largest amount since July 2012; cover was 3.1x, the highest since January 2018. Direct participation was in line with recent averages, and indirects took a higher share than recent sales, leaving dealers with the lowest since last November. The 5s auction was similar, but to a lesser extent, stopping through by 0.7bps.  Both auctions highlight that, despite projections of the US deficit rising to above USD 3trln in 2020, demand is still strong for shorter-dated Treasuries; some have suggested that this is as the market eyes potential yield curve control from the Fed, which isn’t likely to be a feature of Wednesday’s confab, though will be a key issue into the June FOMC, where some believe that the Fed might pledge to leave rates at the effective lower bound for a couple of years, supported by its action in controlling short-term yields.

analysis_details: Another session of chunky losses for crude futures, albeit off the lows, again led by the nearby contracts as storage concerns linger and participants move further out the crude term structure. The June WTI futures were particularly hit after the USO fund announced that between today and month end, it would withdraw any exposure to the June contract, and increase exposure further down the curve and even into 2021. Elsewhere, the DoE announced that the SPR had seen stocks build by 1.1mln bbls over the week ending April 24th – a somewhat expected update, but given recent builds (e.g. +20mln in US weekly crude stocks), the 1.1mln will have little balancing effect. Participants looking for a more stable oil market in the coming weeks will likely be disappointed, Goldman Sachs warns, “commodities are spot assets, not anticipatory assets and must clear current supply and demand, which still remain extremely out of balance in all markets.” The bank caveats that the market is now at an inflection phase with rebalancing having commenced, although could take between eight-to-twelve weeks before it believes it can confidently argue that a bottom has been made.

Daily FX Wrap: Usd/Jpy drifting down post-BoJ and pre-FOMC
content:
YEN

The BoJ left benchmark rates on hold as universally expected, but removed QE limits for JGBs and raised the pace of corporate bond purchases in line with reports ahead of April’s policy meeting. However, despite removing price momentum from its forward guidance and Governor Kuroda’s subsequent downbeat/dovish press conference the Yen gradually appreciated against the Buck to test a decent 1.2 bn expiry option at the 107.00 strike for Monday’s NY cut before bouncing. Moreover, the headline pair appeared to defy convention and direction normally associated with wider risk sentiment that improved on more signs of global economies planning exit strategies from various states of COVID-19 lockdown.

AUD/NZD

The Antipodean Dollars have been outperforming from the outset on the aforementioned loosening coronavirus restrictions ticket, with NZ apparently ready to start reopening as soon as tomorrow and just after Anzac Day. Nevertheless, the Aussie remains in pole position down under and across the major grid, with Aud/Usd holding above key Fib resistance at 0.6450 vs Nzd/Usd hovering around 0.6050 as the cross climbed towards 1.0675 ahead of NZ trade data later on Tuesday.

GBP/CAD

Sterling derived some traction from UK PM Johnson returning to action, but lost momentum circa 1.2450 against the Greenback and 0.8710 vs the Euro after he refrained from announcing any firm date to end lockdown and warned that the country is at the moment of maximum risk. Cable retreated towards 1.2400 and Eur/Gbp rebounded to test the 200 DMA (0.8733) amidst some talk of early month end RHS demand. Note, Chancellor Sunak rolled out more financial provisions for small businesses in the form of fully guaranteed loans with the government to pay interest for the first year, but the Pound was largely unaffected. Similarly, the Loonie shrugged off another collapse in crude prices to trade mostly midway or near the bottom of a 1.4116-1.4040 range, with Usd/Cad capped by the DXY waning on attempts to climb above the 100.000 mark in advance of month end (with a UK clearer flagging moderate selling).

EUR/NOK/CHF/SEK 

The Euro has been relatively restrained ahead of the Fed and ECB amidst low expectations of any fresh policy stimulus from either, but the bar not high for surprises given the scale of nCoV fallout in the US and Eurozone. Hence, Eur/Usd was tightly bound between 1.0861-10 parameters and considerably narrower for the most part, though the single currency pared back a chunk of its losses vs the Franc following another big rise in Swiss bank sight deposits. Indeed, Eur/Chf bounced firmly to around 1.0580 and Usd/Chf spent the bulk of the session nearer 0.9766 than 0.9713. Elsewhere, whippy trade in Scandinavia saw the Swedish Krona steal a march early on as the Norwegian Crown took heed of the aforementioned weakness in oil, but the tables turn on some jitters before the Riksbank policy meeting on Tuesday where the repo rate path may be lowered.

EM

Intervention from the BCB and HKMA, albeit for distinctly different reasons as the Real reeled again in stark contrast to the Hong Kong Dollar staying close to the top of its pegged band, while the Rand celebrated SA Freedom Day with the aid of a lifeline extended to at least 1 of the country’s ailing stated-owned entities. In the same vein, respite for the Mexican Peso against the backdrop of crude’s plight as jobless rates beat consensus by a hefty margin.

subject: ECB PEPP EUR +26.046bln on April 24 vs. Prev. EUR +19.97bln on April 13; Total holding EUR 96.72bln (Prev. EUR 70.674bln)
ECB APP: PSPP EUR +9.113bln (Prev. EUR -2.155bln), CSPP EUR +0.77bln (Prev. EUR +1.381bln), CBPP3 EUR -0.010bln (Prev. EUR +1.515bln), ABSPP EUR -0.386bln (Prev. EUR -0.194bln)
analysis_details:
• ECB purchased a total (net) EUR 9.487bln across the APP vs. last weeks purchase of just (net) EUR 0.547bln, which is an increase of 1634% W/W. Marking a significant increase in the APP; but, this is caveated by the prior week displaying a significant drop on typical figures particularly for the PSPP and ABSPP components.
  • PEPP was EUR +20.05bln vs. Prev. EUR 19.97bln, an increase of just 0.4%. Chiming with some observations recently that the pace of purchases for the PEPP appears to be relatively steady/comfortably around this region.
  • Focus within the purchases remains most firmly on PEPP, as desks see the current EUR 750bln as being exhausted around September/October in the event the Bank continues purchases roughly at the rate it has been so far. As such, much attention for this week’s ECB meeting will be on whether this amount is raised with some desks calling for it to be increased to as much as EUR 2trl, though its not clear as to whether such a figure would be allotted in one go or in stages as it is deemed necessary. ING posit that if the upper limit is not expanded this week then it should be done by the June 4th ECB meeting at the latest.
  • Following an announcement last week that the ECB has taken steps to mitigate the impact of potential debt downgraded on collateral availability focus at this week’s meeting in terms of purchases will also be on whether the Bank could ‘fallen angels’ to its purchase programme. However, the immediate necessity for such a move has perhaps been mitigated by S&P not downgrading Italy as was feared for Friday; but, focus remain on other ratings for Italy in the near-term with the next scheduled rating being Moody’s on May 8th (currently, Baa3).

subject: US EQUITY OPEN: Indices open firmer across the board amid optimistic reopening procedures; losses in energy caps gains
analysis_details:
MACRO: Equities have started the week on the front foot amid DM economies making further steps to reopening, and perhaps more importantly, faith in a COVID-19 treatment to avoid similar outbreaks/lockdowns; note that results on Gilead’s (GILD) remdesivir for use on extreme/severe cases in the US are expected to be released in the coming days, which given the markets recent sensitivity to updates around the drug, will be closely watched by participants. Stimulus remains supportive ahead of the ECB and Fed meetings this week, with the former meeting likely to be more exciting given current debate over a European fiscal package, although attention on the Fed lies very much around its intentions for its asset purchase programmes going ahead (UBS believes the June meeting will contain more details). Meanwhile this morning, oil prices are again taking a tumble, at odds with equities compared to the synchrony last week. Yields are a couple of basis points higher across the Treasury curve, with upcoming 2- and 5-year auctions weighing on the front-end, although how much further they can rise appears limited given growing expectations for front-end YCC from the Fed. While the positive risk appetite is supporting activity currencies at the expense of the dollar.

SECTORS: The majority of sectors open in the green with Energy the only one in negative territory as oil prices take a turn for the worst while the bankruptcy from Diamond Offshore (DO) also adds to concerns in the shale industry. On the flip side, Financials, Real Estate and Consumer Discretionary lead the way, with the former likely benefiting from marginally higher yields.

STOCK SPECIFICS: Apple (AAPL) is reportedly delaying its 2020 iPhones production ramp-up by approximately one month, although it still plans to release four new iPhones later in the year and is looking to slash H2 production by up to 20%, according to WSJ citing sources. Boeing Company (BA)) announced it has terminated the JV agreement with Embraer (ERJ), who believe the termination was wrongfully claimed and made false claims. Meanwhile, two influential proxy advisory firms have recommended that BA shareholders vote against key board members to protest how it handled the 737 MAX crisis, according to WSJ. Diamond Offshore (DO) filed for its Chapter 11 bankruptcy, weighing on Lowe’s (L) who own a majority stake in the co. and will face a USD 1.5bln loss from the bankruptcy. General Motors (GM) announced it has extended USD 3.6bln under its revolving credit facility to April 2022, while suspending its quarterly cash dividend and share repurchase programme.

BULLISH ON THE CONSUMER: Morgan Stanley takes a more contrarian view on the US consumer, suggesting that the group went into this downturn firmer than the GFC and that recent market excesses were centred in the corporate channel. The analysts say the dips in consumer confidence and retail sentiment are not as bad as that in the GFC and 1990 recessions, believing that levels won’t need to fall to the same extent as before. Furthermore, the bank says recent stimulus has been directed at the consumer, unlike prior crashes.

MARKET CONCENTRATION: Morgan Stanley highlight the growing market concentration of the top five market cap companies in the SPX (currently MSFT, AAPL, AMZN, FB, JNJ) which since 2016, has grown from just above 10%, to just below 20% - a level not seen since the 1970’s Nifty Fifty era. The tailwind for such concentration has been a combination of declining equity risk premium, earnings resilience and rising valuations, noting that the current strength has been relative expected earnings resilience to the rest of the index/market. Looking ahead, the bank sees room for reversal in a COVID-19 recovery, “we expect the market cap giants to underperform cyclical and smaller cap companies during the recovery as relative earnings strength reverses.” Supporting the reversal call, MS says the timing of bottoming earnings estimates is important, which it does believe is now occurring as it cites week-over-week net change in earnings revision breadth turning (modestly) positive last week for the first time since late January; “In the last two recessions, once the revision factor turned up, it didn't look back.”

content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

April 27th, 2020

The Daily US Equity Opening News is uploaded at 1400BST/0800CDT recapping all the overnight equity news

  • US equity futures are pointing to gains at the open with sentiment boosted by reopening hopes across the globe and treatment hopes. NY Governor Cuomo noted the guidelines from the CDC will be followed by the Phase One stage of the reopening cycle may begin on May 15th. Elsewhere, Italy will begin to lift its lockdown restrictions from May 4th. Meanwhile, results from a trial of Gilead’s (GILD) remdeisivir in critical/severe patients is due in the coming days.
  • This week’s Barron’s articles note how investors may be too optimistic on restaurant stocks such as MCD. SBUX, YUM, CMG, and DRI who are up between 50-125% from the March lows, highlighting social distancing measures are likely to be in effect once they’re open. Elsewhere, Barron’s write that “oily industrials” have received big bargains from the lower oil prices, naming Flowserve (FLS), Emerson Electric (EMR), United Rentals (URI) and Fluor (FLR). A separate author notes that Harley Davison (HOG) could be headed for a serious wipeout this coming week. On food delivery names (UBER, GRUB), it noted that while deliveries are soaring, it does not see the same benefits as other stay-at-home stocks like Zoom (ZM) and Amazon (ZMZN).
  • Of note for Cruise liners (NCLH, RCL), both listed names received support from Germany where they will receive a 122-month debt holiday, which will free up USD 386mln in liquidity for NCLH, and RCL will add USD 250mln.
  • Of note for Airliners (LUV, AAL, UAL, DAL), the sector received additional funds from the PPP worth up to USD 9.5bl from the US Treasury.
  • Of note for Semiconductors (SOX), Oppenheimer reduced estimates for the group once again with the desk suggesting data points to a deeper drag on demand than initially expected. The desk highlights the announcement from TXN which sees a glimpse of headwinds, particularly in the industrial and auto sectors. The desk also notes the smartphone area is challenged despite new devices as consumer spending falls amid a rise in unemployment and sees smartphone units down 10% globally this year.

DOW JONES

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) is delaying its 2020 iPhones production ramp-up by approximately a month; still plans to release four new iPhones later in the year; looking to slash H2 production by up to 20%, according to WSJ citing sources.
  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) announced it has terminated the JV agreement with Embraer (ERJ), who believe the termination was wrongfully claimed and made false claims. Meanwhile, two influential proxy advisory firms have recommended that BA shareholders vote against key board members to protest how it handled the 737 MAX crisis, according to WSJ. Elsewhere, French rival Airbus (AIR FP) announced it is “bleeding cash” at a rate that threatens the Co’s existence, adding that a third of its business has been lost in the past few weeks.

  • Regeneron (REGN) (Health Care/Biotechnology) and Sanofi (SAN FP) Phase III trial for Libtayo showed highly significant improvement in overall survival, thus trial was stopped early. It also announced its Kevzara trial in COVID-19 patients is rapidly advancing and plans to initiate clinical trials in June, although the drug did not benefit hospitalized patients who were not on ventilators. Still, the study will continue for those who require a ventilator or oxygen support.
  • Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) is reportedly calling workers back to its vehicle assembly plant in the US from next week.
  • T-Mobile (TMUS) (Communication Services/Wireless Telecommunication Services) former CEO John Legere announced he has retired from the board of directors a few weeks ahead of schedule to pursue other options.

  • CMS Energy (CMS) (Utilities/Multi-Utilities) Q1 20 (USD): Adj. EPS USD 0.86 (exp. 0.79), revenue 1.86bln (exp. 2.08bln). FY20 adj. EPS view backed at 2.64-2.68 (exp. 2.63).
  • General Electric (GE) (Industrials/Industrial Conglomerates) profits are reportedly threatened amid COVID-19, according to reports.
  • General Motors (GM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) announced it has extended USD 3.6bln under its revolving credit facility to April 2022, while suspending its quarterly cash dividend and share repurchase programme.
  • Loews Corp. (L) (Financials/Multi-line Insurance) carries a USD 1.5bln loss from Diamond Offshore Drilling (DO) bankruptcy; it will record a non-cash Q2 loss from carrying overvalue. Note Loews holds the largest share in DO, at 53%.
  • Stryker Corp. (SYK) (Health Care/Health Care Equipment) announced it has extended its cash tender offer for all outstanding shares of Wright Medical (WMGI) and is now scheduled to expire at 1700 ET on June 30th, 2020.
  • Abbott Laboratories (ABT) (Health Care/Health Care Equipment) has been chosen by Italy to supply 150k blood testing kits to screen for the coronavirus.

OTHER

  • Adidas (ADS GY, ADDYY) (Consumer Discretionary/Textiles, Apparel & Luxury Goods) Q1 net EUR 26mln vs. Prev. EUR 633mln YY. Revenue EUR 4.75bln vs. Prev. EUR 5.88bln. Co. notes that over 70% of the Co’s global store base remains closed. E-Commerce saw a significant boost of 55% in constant currency. Co. had a cash position of EUR 1.97bln at the end of March.

Co. notes that COVID-19 restrictions are adversely impacting parts of the business. Q1 litigation/risk effect at EUR 368mln – with no Roundup trial scheduled to begin before end-June. Co. says it is not possible to reliably assess effects until later in the year, forecasts provided in February do not consider the pandemic. Pharmaceuticals EBITDA +7.3% YY to EUR 1.594bln. Sales in eye medicine Eylea +1.1% YY. Sales of oral Anticoagulant Xarelto +18.8% YY. Consumer Health sales +13.5% YY.

  • Deutsche Bank (DBK GY, DB) (Financials/Diversified Banks) Prelim Q1 net EUR 66mln vs. Prev. EUR 201mln YY. Pretax EUR +206mln vs. Exp. EUR -269mln (Prev. EUR 292mln). Revenue EUR 6.4bln vs. Prev. EUR 6.35bln. Provisions for credit losses EUR 500mln vs. Prev. EUR 140mln. Co. notes that FY20 CET1 may modestly and temporarily fall below its prior target of at least 12.5% vs.12.8% at end-Q1 (above the 10.4% regulator minimum). Co. said it will suspend capital targets to “it can support clients and the broader economy in times of crisis”. Co. said it was unlikely that it would reach its 2020 target of having a 4.5% leverage ratio. Co. affirms FY20 guidance. Note: Co. is due to report earnings on Wednesday, but key numbers were released as they varied materially vs. analysts’ forecasts, according to a spokesman.
  • Diamond Offshore (DO) (Energy/Energy Equipment & Services) announced it has filed started voluntary chapter 11 proceedings.
  • Etsy (ETSY) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) is reportedly seeing demand for face masks at similar levels to Cyber Monday, according to FT.

subject: ANALYSIS: BOJ removes bond-buying caps, but market implications are minimal, Citi thinks
content:
• The key interest rate was left unchanged at -0.1% and forward guidance tweaked in which the reference to price momentum was dropped - as touted by sources last week. The Bank reaffirmed its pledge to further ease without hesitation if necessary, whilst Governor Kuroda did not rule out deeper negative rates as a future option but said it's hard to see rates declining. 
  • The Bank of Japan removed its JPY 80trln limit on buying government bonds, and can now buy an unlimited amount of government bonds to meet its objective to keep 10-year yields around zero; the move comes at a time when the government will be boosting debt issuance to finance its COVID-19 response. The BOJ said it would buy JGBs and short-term securities "actively" to keep markets stable. It also increased the scale of buying commercial paper and corporate debt (almost trebling from JPY 7.4trln to JPY 20trln/year). 
  • Its forecasts saw the central bank cut its forecasts and projected that it will miss its 2% inflation goal for three more years. Elsewhere, the bank broadened accepted collateral in its operations. 
  • Citi's analysts do not think the announcement has much material impact for financial market players, and the bank explains: 1) the Fed has already announced unlimited bond purchases effectively and has been enacting this; 2) the BOJ has decreased JGB purchases remarkably since 2017; purchased amounts, which totalled close to JPY 80trln in 2016, decreased to only JPY 15trln last year, and its annualised size has grown only to JPY 30trln since this February when purchases reaccelerated; 3) under the current YCC framework, asset purchases play only a secondary role.

Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 27th April 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses are stronger this morning following the APAC lead, US futures are firmer but to a lesser extent ahead of Fed and on the busiest week of earnings this quarter
  • BoJ kept NIRP at -0.1% and long term JGB yield target at around 0% but pledged to buy unlimited JGBs and increased its purchases of corporate bonds and commercial paper
  • New York Governor Cuomo said the state will follow the CDC’s recommendation to wait until hospitalization rates decline for 14 days before opening up
  • FX sees the DXY softer this morning with major peers broadly outperforming the USD
  • Looking ahead, highlights include ECB purchases, US 2 and 5yr supply

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

Reports noted that preliminary results from a Remdesivir test by Chinese scientists found it may reduce sperm count in mice. (Newswires) Separately, Japanese gov't are reportedly to apply for special approval to streamline the procedure for remdesivir* on the condition it receives approval overseas, Kyodo citing Gov't Officials. (Kyodo)

US is to cap the amount each bank can lend under the coronavirus relief program with the Small Business Administration to impose a maximum amount for individual lenders at 10% of the Paycheck Protection Program and pace the applications filed. (Newswires)

New York Governor Cuomo said the state will follow the CDC’s recommendation to wait until hospitalization rates decline for 14 days before opening up and outlined that phase 1 will involve construction and manufacturing activities which pose low risk, while phase 2 to be based on a business-by-business analysis of how essential it is and the associated risks. Furthermore, Governor Cuomo noted that the number of deaths in the state from coronavirus increased by 367 on Saturday vs. Prev. 437 on Friday, while there were comments from New York City Mayor De Blasio that the city needs USD 7.4bln from the government to offset impact from the outbreak. (Newswires/Fox)

Italy coronavirus cases rose by 2324 to a total of 197,675 and death toll increased by 260 vs. Prev. 415 which was the smallest daily increase since March 14th. In related news, Italy PM Conte announced to begin lifting the lockdown from May 4th in which bars and restaurants will be able to provide home deliveries and retailers are to reopen on May 18th, while he added that it is reasonable to expect schools to remain shut until the end of the school year. (Newswires)

Spain's coronavirus cases stand at 209,465 (Prev. 207,634), deaths rise by 331 to 23,521 (Prev. 23,190), according to the Health Ministry. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson could ease lockdown restrictions before the May 7 deadline and is expected to announce plans for easing lockdown as early as this week after returning to Downing Street. (Telegraph) This morning, in a speech outside Downing Street PM Johnson says we are making progress on COVID-19 and we are passing through the peak. However, he noted that the UK is at the moment of maximum risk and refuses to throw away efforts of the UK public and allow another wave of infections. Johnson concluded by noting that he cannot say when changes will be made but will say more in the coming days.

National Medical Director of NHS England Stephen Powis stated we now have a very definite trend of reduced hospitalizations and that it is highly likely there will be different types of measures combined which will keep transmission rate down. (Newswires)

China said there are no longer any coronavirus patients at hospitals in Wuhan and it was also reported that the Hong Kong government is considering easing social distancing measures. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly positive with sentiment underpinned by optimism regarding the reopening of global economies after some US states began to reopen businesses and with Italy, Spain and France preparing to ease restrictions after recording their lowest death tolls in a month. ASX 200 (+1.5%) was led higher by tech and industrials with sentiment also supported by loosening of lockdown measures after Queensland announced to permit some outings from next Saturday. However, upside was initially restricted by weakness in the largest weighted financials sector after big 4 bank NAB posted a 51% slump in cash profit and unveiled plans for a substantial share placement, while Nikkei 225 (+2.7%) outperformed amid a weaker currency and the BoJ policy announcement where the central bank announced further measures including a shift to unlimited bond buying as widely speculated. Hang Seng (+1.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) were also higher with Hong Kong surging as its government was said to consider easing social distancing controls and the mainland somewhat lagged after weak Chinese Industrial Profits which contracted by almost 35% Y/Y. Finally, 10yr JGBs were initially lower amid the gains in stocks and similar pressure in T-notes, although JGBs prices were later boosted after the BoJ policy announcement in which the central bank also upped its corporate bond and commercial paper purchases with the maximum limits of purchases from a single issuer upped to JPY 500bln and JPY 300bln respectively from JPY 100bln.

PBoC skipped open market operations and are net neutral on the day. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0703 vs. Exp. 7.0687 (Prev. 7.0803) Chinese Industrial Profits (Mar) Y/Y -34.9% (Prev. 5.4%); YTD (Mar) Y/Y -36.7% (Prev. -38.3%). (Newswires)

China began the Standing Committee of the NPC plenary session where they will decide on the date for when the NPC will take place. (Xinhua)

BoJ kept NIRP at -0.1% and long term JGB yield target at around 0% but pledged to buy unlimited JGBs and increased its purchases of corporate bonds and commercial paper. BoJ said it will buy up to JPY 20tln of corporate bonds, as well as relax rules for corporate bonds and commercial paper purchases, while it will expand the type of assets it accepts as collateral for loan programme to tackle coronavirus. Furthermore, BoJ said it won’t hesitate to ease further if required and removed price momentum from its forward guidance in which it stated it expects short and long-term policy rates to remain at current or lower levels. (Newswires)

BoJ Governor Kuroda does not rule out deeper Negative Interest Rate Policy from future options; won't allow 10yr bond yields rise for the time being; will do whatever is necessary as a Central Bank to respond to the crisis. (Newswires)

BoJ’s Outlook Report stated Japan's economy is to remain in a severe situation due to the spread of coronavirus and that uncertainty on Japan's economic outlook is extremely high but noted the economy is likely to improve on pent-up demand once virus effect subsides and that inflation is likely to gradually accelerate as economy improves.

Real GDP   

Fiscal 2019 forecast lowered to between -0.4% and -0.1% from 0.8%. Fiscal 2020 forecast lowered to between -5.0% and -3.0% from 0.8%. Fiscal 2021 forecast revised to between 2.8% and 2.9% from 1.1%. Fiscal 2022 forecast at between 0.8% and 1.6%.

Core CPI

Fiscal 2019 forecast kept at 0.6%. Fiscal 2020 forecast lowered to between -0.3% and -0,7% from 1.0%. Fiscal 2021 forecast lowered to between 0% and 0.7% from 1.4%. Fiscal 2020 forecast at between 0.4% and 1.0%

US

White House Adviser Hassett said the US unemployment rate is likely to reach 16% or higher when this month’s jobs report is released. (Newswires)

US Treasury's semi-annual currency manipulation reportedly has been delayed given COVID-19, according to Taiwanese Central Bank sources. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson is set to take personal charge of Brexit talks as he returns to work and looks to put pressure on the EU to move red lines on areas such as regulatory alignment and fisheries. (Times)

EY ITEM Club estimates it will 3 years to return to levels pre-coronavirus levels and forecasts half of UK consumer spending this year will be delayed or lost. (Newswires)

European Commission is to temporarily ease rules on leverage ratio calculation to help banks lend more in pandemic, to propose allowing banks to opt into relief from the bad loan provisioning rule, according to sources. (Newswires) Separately, EU is reportedly considering state aid via subordinated debt injections, reports state.

Italian Foreign Minister and 5-Star Leader Di Maio clarified that his remarks that Italy must be “pragmatic” in talks referred to discussions with the EU over aid tools and not the ESM, while he stated they continue to see the ESM as an inadequate tool, (Newswires)

S&P affirmed United Kingdom at AA; Outlook Stable and affirmed Italy at BBB; Outlook Negative, while it affirmed Portugal at BBB; Outlook revised to Stable from Positive and affirmed Greece at BB-; Outlook revised to Stable from Positive on adverse effects of COVID-19. Fitch affirmed Netherlands at AAA; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Japanese media report claimed that North Korea Leader Kim was in a vegetative state following heart surgery. In related news, North Korea state radio issued a statement reportedly from Leader Kim in appreciation of workers furnishing Samjiyon but made no comments on his health or whereabouts. (Yonhap)

US Secretary of State Pompeo is said to prepare a legal argument that the US remains a participant of JCPOA as an effort to pressure Iran and extend arms embargo. (NYT)

Southern Transitional Council separatists which are backed by the United Arab Emirates, scrapped a peace agreement with the Saudi-backed government in Yemen and declared a state of emergency, while the Saudi-led coalition called for an end to any escalation and immediate return to Riyadh agreement. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities trade comfortably on a firmer footing [Euro Stoxx 50 +2.2%], as the risk-appetite from the APAC session followed through and intensifies as European economies near an easing lockdown measures – with Italy to begin its lifting from May 4th, Spain relieving some of its strictest measures and UK to reportedly update on measures as early as this week. Bourses see broad-based gains but Italy’s FTSE MIB (+2.5%) modestly outperforms after S&P refrained from downgrading the country’s rating on Friday. Sectors all reside in positive territory, with Financials leading the gains – propped up by Deutsche Bank (+11.2%) earnings – whilst energy underperforms amid price action in the oil complex. This performance is also reflected in the sector breakdown with Banks the outperformer and Oil & Gas the laggard, Travel & Leisure resides towards the top amid lockdown lifts across Europe and US. In terms of individual movers, earnings see more focus on German firms; DAX-giant Bayer (+2.7%) sees impetus from Q1 revenue and adj. EBITDA topping analyst estimates, and improvement in EPS and gains across all its units – the Co. accounts for 6.8% of the DAX 30. Adidas (+2.5%) conformed to the broad risk-appetite after nursing opening losses of over 3%, which initially emanated from dismal earnings alongside a failure to provide FY20 guidance. Adidas noted that 70% of its global stores remain shut. Deutsche Bank (+11.2%) shares soar on an early earnings release in which Q1 pre-tax posted a profit of EUR 206mln vs. Exp. loss 269mln, albeit the group notes that it is unlikely to meet its FY20 leverage ratio target of 4.5%. A spokesman said the release of key metrics was due to a significant divergence with analyst forecasts – Commerzbank (+6.5%) rises in sympathy. Elsewhere, Lufthansa (+7.2%) was propelled at the open after Germany’s Economy Minister stated the group must get a chance to return to profitability, whilst the Co. is also seeking a EUR 290mln loan from the Belgium gov’t for its Belgian subsidiary. Similarly, Air France-KLM (+4.7%) and Renault (+5%) see upside after the French gov’t announced a EUR 7bln package for the former, whilst mulling a EUR 5bln loan guarantee for the latter. On the flip side, Airbus (-1.5%) is pressured amid comments from its CEO regarding the severity of the group’s position – stating that the Co. is “bleeding cash” at a rate which threatens the Co’s existence, adding that a third of its business has been lost in the past few weeks.

FX

USD - The Greenback has retreated further against G10 counterparts and almost across the board, with the DXY struggling to retain grip or sight of the 100.000 mark within a 100.320-99.847 range amidst an upturn in broad risk sentiment that is only really being tainted by more weakness in crude oil on bearish supply/storage-demand dynamics.

AUD/NZD - The Aussie and Kiwi are both seemingly reaping the rewards of relative progress and success on the coronavirus front as the respective Governments eye reopening schedules. Aud/Usd is now firmly back above 0.6400 and pivoting 0.6450, while Nzd/Usd is straddling 0.6050 and Aud/Nzd is probing above 1.0650 on Anzac Day. Note, NZ markets return on Tuesday and will be looking towards trade data for some fundamental direction/impetus in the same vein as Australia’s preliminary report last week.

GBP - The next best major and the Pound could well be receiving another Boris boost as the UK PM returns to his official residence to resume duties with an encouraging update on Britain’s battle to combat COVID-19. Cable has reclaimed 1.2400+ status and Eur/Gbp is meandering between 0.8754-10 parameters with the cross retreating below its 200 DMA again.

CAD/JPY/EUR - The Loonie is also outpacing its US peer even though oil prices are tanking again, with Usd/Cad under 1.4100 ahead of somewhat dated Canadian securities balances for February, while the Yen has strengthened in wake of the BoJ policy meeting despite further stimulus via QE as speculated ahead of the event. Usd/Jpy got close to 107.00 before a mild bounce that could have been option expiry related given 1.2 bn rolling off at the strike, but also technical as strong chart support sits just beneath the round number circa 106.93/92 (April 15th and 1st lows). On the flip-side, 2 bn expiries from 107.50 to 107.60 may cap the headline pair, while the Euro has 1.1 bn at 1.0800 to provide a cushion alongside a raft of options in to the Fed and ECB on Wednesday and Thursday respectively.

CHF/NOK/SEK - The Swiss Franc and Norwegian Krona are marginal underperformers following latest weekly sight deposits revealing another significant rise in bank coffers, while the latter is eyeing the aforementioned weakness in crude, like the Russian Rouble. However, the Swedish Crown continues to hold up better on the premise that the Riksbank will stick to its guns on rates tomorrow in favour of non-standard policy measures should the situation warrant more than already implemented. Hence, Usd/Chf idling within a 0.9744-13 band, Eur/Chf off recent near 1.0500 lows between 1.0532-58, Eur/Nok rotating around 11.5000, Usd/RUB encircling 74.5000 and Eur/Sek still suppressed sub-10.9000.

EM - Some much needed respite for the Rand that has pared declines from 19.1000+ amidst the aforementioned revival in risk appetite, but Usd/Zar may be impacted by thinner than normal volumes due to SA’s Freedom Day holiday, while the Hong Dollar remains close to the top of its peg vs the Dollar prompting the HKMA to intervene again.

FIXED

It’s been a gradual fade against the backdrop of broad risk-on positioning in asset markets with the exception of crude that is sliding again, and June WTI especially, but Bunds, Gilts and US Treasuries are all back underwater to varying degrees, as the 10 year UK benchmark nestles just above a fresh 136.84 Liffe low. Ahead, only Dallas Fed manufacturing after ECB QE updates and before US short end supply that is front-loaded this week due to the FOMC

COMMODITIES

Nigerian oil export plans for June have been delayed as NNPC undertakes talks with stakeholders and oil majors on reining in output, expected to revise down its oil export volumes for May and pare back June flows given OPEC+ cuts, according to sources. (Newswires)

WTI and Brent front-month futures have resumed selling off as storage scarcity continues to weigh on investor sentiment – with the former underperforming amid reports that Cushing, Oklahoma, may hit full capacity soon.  Goldman Sachs believes that storage capacity limits could be tested in as little as three weeks. This week also sees the official implementation of the OPEC+ reduction pact, but some members, including Saudi, have brought forward cuts in a bid to somewhat stabilise the price rout. ING, among other desks, believes that the move is “helpful, [but] it will have little impact on the oil balance in the short term.” Nonetheless, despite the recent geopolitically induced upside in prices – underlying fundamentals remain unchanged. That being said, with major economies set to loosen lockdown restrictions, pressure on demand could start to ease – early signs could be seen in China as refinery activity at independent refiners has been hitting record levels in the Shandong region. WTI June briefly dipped below USD 14.50/bbl to a current base at USD 14.18/bbl (vs. high USD 16.98/bbl), whilst its Brent counterpart sees declines in tandem having tested USD 20/bbl to the downside in early trade (vs. high USD 21.91/bbl). Elsewhere, spot gold sees losses despite a softer Buck, with desks attributing the pressure to improved risk appetite on countries lifting COVID-19 measures. The yellow metal remains comfortably north of USD 1700/oz, having waned off highs of around USD 1720/oz. Copper prices meanwhile remain in the green but somewhat subdued amid a slump in Chinese Industrial profits – prices edging towards USD 2.37/lb vs. high of around USD 2.39/lb. Finally, Dalian iron ore futures recovered as stocks of the raw material fell to their lowest in over 9 months.

In a speech outside Downing Street, PM Johnson says we are making progress on COVID-19 and we are passing through the peak
content:
• We are on the brink of achieving the first clear mission; preventing the NHS being overwhelmed and we are beginning to turn the tide
  • This is the moment of maximum risk
  • He sees the consequences of the lockdown but must recognise the risk of a second spike and allowing the R0 to move above 1
  • Refuses to throw away efforts of the UK public and allow another wave of infections.
  • We are approaching the end of the first phase of this conflict.
  • When we are sure the first phase is over, that will be the time to move on.
  • Cannot say when such changes will be made but will say more in the coming days.
analysis_details: • The UK's five criteria for easing lockdown measures 1) protect the NHS, 2) consistent decline in death rates, 3) lower infection rates across the board, 4) testing and PPE issues under control, 5) prevention of a second peak. (Telegraph)

subject: BoJ has widened ranges for JGB purchases in May across three maturities
content:
• 3-5yr: JPY 200-500bln (Prev. JPY 150-400bln); 5 times (Prev. 6 times in April) 
  • 1-3yr: JPY 200-500bln (Prev. JPY 200-450bln)
  • 5-10yr JPY: 200-500bln (Unch)
analysis_details:
From the decision release: Link

1. Outright purchases of JGBs [COMPETITIVE AUCTION]

  • (1) Bonds to be purchased JGBs with coupons (2-year bonds, 5-year bonds, 10-year bonds, 20-year bonds, 30-year bonds, 40-year bonds, floating-rate bonds, and inflation-indexed bonds).
  • (2) Schedule of purchases The Bank, in principle, will release the schedule of purchases for the following month in advance on the last business day of each month.
  • (3) Amount to be purchased The Bank will conduct purchases in a flexible manner, taking account of market conditions, aiming to achieve the target level of a long-term interest rate specified by the guideline for market operations.
  • (4) Method for auctions A multiple-price competitive auction. JGBs with coupons (excluding floating-rate bonds and inflation-indexed bonds): Counterparties bid their "desired yield spreads," which are calculated by subtracting "benchmark yields" from the yields at which counterparties seek to sell to the Bank. Floating-rate bonds and inflation-indexed bonds: Counterparties bid their "desired price spreads," which are calculated by subtracting "benchmark prices" from the prices at which counterparties seek to sell to the Bank.

2. Outright purchases of JGBs [FIXED RATE]

  • (1) Bonds to be purchased Among JGBs with coupons (2-year bonds, 5-year bonds, 10-year bonds, 20-year bonds, 30-year bonds, and 40-year bonds), mainly on-the-run issues.
  • (2) Schedule of purchases The Bank will conduct the auctions as needed, such as when the level of the yield curve changes substantially.
  • (3) Amount to be purchased Depending on market conditions, the Bank may set the purchase size per auction to a fixed amount or to an unlimited amount.
  • (4) Method for auctions Purchasing yields will be set per auction, by indicating the yield spreads from the benchmark yields which the Bank determines separately.

3. Outright purchases of treasury discount bills (T-Bills) 

  • Regarding purchases of T-Bills, conducted as part of money market operations, the Bank will decide the purchase size per auction considering the effects on financial markets. The Bank will purchase about 500 billion to 3.0 trillion yen of T-Bills per auction for the time being.

subject: UK debt and STIR futures straddling parity
content: A blank domestic slate to start the new week and little independent impetus from a rather ominous overnight report from E&Y suggesting it could take 3 years for the economy to return to its pre-coronavirus state, but Gilts have benefited from a firmer rebound in Bunds to 172.91 and are managing to keep tabs on the 137.00 handle between 136.96-137.13 parameters vs their previous 137.06 settlement as a result. Similarly, the Short Sterling strip is sitting tight either side of parity within a -0.5/+1 tick band awaiting more news on COVID-19 and lockdown plans from PM Johnson who has now returned to 10 Downing Street. Ahead, a considerably quieter UK calendar until Friday’s final manufacturing PMI and BoE lending data, but month end prior to that and more global Central Bank policy meetings, like the Fed and ECB.

subject: Bunds: decent bounce given stock and Eurozone periphery outperformance
content: Almost all change for the core Eurozone bond as Italian BTPs lead a recovery at the margins in relief that S&P reaffirmed the sovereign’s triple B rating along with Portugal, while Rome plans to lift some COVID-19 restrictions from this time next week following a further slowdown in the spread. However, the 10 year German debt future has pared a chunk of its overnight losses and just popped above opening levels within a 172.23-72 range vs last Friday’s 172.76 close heading in to the EU cash bourse opens while their Italian equivalent hovers just below 139.00 from sub-137.00 pre-S&P. Ahead, and perhaps more pertinent for Italy and the rest of the periphery could be latest weekly QE tallies from the ECB with the PEPP of particular interest given reports on Friday that the BoI was buying for the programme ‘slightly’ more than average Italian paper.

subject: BoJ Governor Kuroda says closely watching COVID-19 impact, will ease further and without hesitation if necessary - price momentum has been lost for now
analysis_details:
REMINDER: 

  • BoJ kept NIRP at -0.1% and long term JGB yield target at around 0% but pledged to buy unlimited JGBs and increased its purchases of corporate bonds and commercial paper. BoJ said it will buy up to JPY 20tln of corporate bonds, as well as relax rules for corporate bonds and commercial paper purchases, while it will expand the type of assets it accepts as collateral for loan programme to tackle coronavirus. Furthermore, BoJ said it won’t hesitate to ease further if required and removed price momentum from its forward guidance in which it stated it expects short and long-term policy rates to remain at current or lower levels.
  • BoJ’s Outlook Report stated Japan's economy is to remain in a severe situation due to the spread of coronavirus and that uncertainty on Japan's economic outlook is extremely high but noted the economy is likely to improve on pent-up demand once virus effect subsides and that inflation is likely to gradually accelerate as economy improves.
