Daily European Equity Opening News
content:
27 April 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0200CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real-time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly positive with sentiment underpinned by optimism regarding the reopening of global economies after some US states began to reopen businesses and with Italy, Spain, and France preparing to ease restrictions after recording their lowest death tolls in a month. ASX 200 (+1.5%) was led higher by tech and industrials with sentiment also supported by loosening of lockdown measures after Queensland announced to permit some outings from next Saturday. However, upside was initially restricted by weakness in the largest weighted financials sector after big 4 banks NAB posted a 51% slump in cash profit and unveiled plans for a substantial share placement, while Nikkei 225 (+2.6%) outperformed amid a weaker currency and the BoJ policy announcement where the central bank announced further measures including a shift to unlimited bond-buying as widely speculated. Hang Seng (+1.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.7%) were also higher with Hong Kong surging as its government was said to consider easing social distancing controls and the mainland somewhat lagged after weak Chinese Industrial Profits which contracted by almost 35% Y/Y.

FTSE 100

Carnival (CCL LN) – Reports note that before the Fed’s lending programme, Co. was in discussions for high interest-rate loans from a consortium of hedge funds. (WSJ)

Centrica (CNA LN) – FT’s Elder writes that in-spite of the Co’s problems, management has a chance of a turnaround in the current environment and as an initial step shareholder should relinquish dividends. (FT)

Dixons Carphone (DC/ LN) - Co.'s boss has warned that some sales that move online during the current lockdown might never return to physical stores as the Co. prepares to open with "extreme care". (Telegraph)

HSBC (HSBA LN)/ Standard Charted (STAN LN) – Analysts believe that Hong Kong banks’ results will likely be hit by larger bad loan reserves. (SCMP) For reference, HSBC is due to report on Apr 28th and Standard Chartered on Apr 29th.

UK Retailers - The number of customers in shops will be limited and will be separated by floor markings under reopening guidelines provided by the BRC. (Telegraph)

UK Lenders – BoE’s Prudential Regulation Authority representatives have reportedly, in the prev. week, spoken with high-level banking executives to advise them not to ‘kitchen sink’ provisions in Q1, according to sources. (FT)

UK Airlines – Airlines UK CEO Alserslade has reportedly written to the Treasury seeking certainty regarding the COVID-19 job retention scheme; calling for this to be extended beyond June or else such names could see another crisis. (Sky News)

UK Housebuilders – Knight Frank predicts that 104k houses will be privately constructed in 2020, -35% vs. official estimates from March. (City AM)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Tui (TUI LN) – Co. has lost its major partner, DER Touritik, which secured customer payments for package tours. Co. is to have special burdens of EUR 130mln. (Süddeutsche Zeitung)

BROKER MOVES

ASTON MARTIN (AML LN) DOWNGRADED TO SELL FROM NEUTRAL AT GOLDMAN SACHS 

BAE SYSTEMS (BA/ LN) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM EQUAL WEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY

MELROSE (MRO LN) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM BUY AT GOLDMAN SACHS

DAX

Adidas (ADS GY) – Q1 net EUR 26mln vs. Prev. EUR 633mln YY. Revenue EUR 4.75bln vs. Prev. EUR 5.88bln. Operating profit EUR 65mln vs. Prev. EUR 875mln. Co. is unable to provide FY20 guidance. Basic EPS from continuing operations -96% YY to EUR 0.13. Co. notes that over 70% of the Co’s global store base remains closed. E-Commerce saw a significant boost of 55% in constant currency. Co. had a cash position of EUR 1.97bln at the end of March. (Newswires) For reference, Co. has a 4.96% weighting in the DAX 30

Bayer (BAYN GY) – Q1 revenue EUR 12.85bln vs. Exp. EUR 12.56bln. Adj. EBITDA EUR 4.39bln vs. Exp. EUR 4.17bln. Core EPS EUR 2.67 vs. Prev. EUR 2.43. Co. notes that COVID-19 restrictions are adversely impacting parts of the business. Q1 litigation/risk effect at EUR 368mln – with no Roundup trial scheduled to begin before end-June. Co. says it is not possible to reliably assess effects until later in the year, forecasts provided in February do not consider the pandemic. Pharmaceuticals EBITDA +7.3% YY to EUR 1.594bln. Sales in eye medicine Eylea +1.1% YY. Sales of oral Anticoagulant Xarelto +18.8% YY. Consumer Health sales +13.5% YY. (Newswires) For reference, Co. has a 6.81% weighting in the DAX 30.

BMW (BMW GY) – Co. is to restart operations at plans in Europe and US as early as May, with its Munich plant set to restart from May 11th. (Newswires)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – Prelim Q1 net EUR 66mln vs. Prev. EUR 201mln YY. Pretax EUR +206mln vs. Exp. EUR -269mln (Prev. EUR 292mln). Revenue EUR 6.4bln vs. Prev. EUR 6.35bln. Provisions for credit losses EUR 500mln vs. Prev. EUR 140mln. Co. notes that FY20 CET1 may modestly and temporarily fall below its prior target of at least 12.5% vs.12.8% at end-Q1 (above the 10.4% regulator minimum). Co. said it will suspend capital targets to “it can support clients and the broader economy in times of crisis”. Co. said it was unlikely that it would reach its 2020 target of having a 4.5% leverage ratio. Co. affirms FY20 guidance. Note: Co. is due to report earnings on Wednesday, but key numbers were released as they varied materially vs. analysts’ forecasts, according to a spokesman. (FT/Newswires) Separately, Co. has reportedly declined a request by US Senators to provide information regarding the Co’s recent business dealings with US President Trump and his family, according to sources. (Newswires)

Lufthansa (LHA GY) – Co. is reportedly seeking a EUR 290mln loan from the Belgian government for its Belgian subsidiary in a bit to avoid bankruptcy. (Newswires) German Economy Minister said Co. must get a chance to be profitable again. (Newswires) Co. is seen opening higher by almost 8%.

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) – Co. is set to restart production at its Wolfsburg car plant, the largest in the world. Separate reports noted that the Co. has extended the factory shutdown at its Puebla plant in Mexico until at least May 18th, whilst it is unclear when operations will return at its Sialo plant. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Sixt (SIX2 GY) – Prelim Q1 operating revenue EUR 484mln vs. Prev. EUR 503.1mln. EBT EUR -5mln vs. Prev. EUR +40mln. (Newswires)

Telefonica Deutschland (O2D GY) – Co. has confirmed the sale of its German radio masts in a deal amounting to EUR 1.5bln. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

CAC

Airbus (AIR FP) – CEO noted that the group is “bleeding cash” at a rate that threatens its existence and will need to apply cost-cutting measures quickly whilst adapting to a changing industry. Co. has lost a third of business in the last few weeks and the recent production cut measures are not the worst-case scenario moves. CEO stated that the Co. has moved quickly to secure credit lines. (FT/Newswires) Separately, Boeing (BA) has ditched its USD 4bln deal to acquire Brazil’s Embraer. (FT)

EDF (EDF FP) – Co. is prepared to submit their planning application for Sizewell C nuclear plant, despite complaints that COVID-19 makes its suitability hard for locals to assess. Note, plant could generate 7% of the UK’s electricity needs. (FT)

Engie (ENGI FP) – S&P cuts rating to “BBB+” from “A-“; outlook revised to “Stable” from “Negative”. Separately, Co. plant the partial return of employees from mid-May. (Newswires)

Renault (RNO FP) – French Finance Minister Le Maire said the government is mulling a EUR 5bln loan guarantee for the Co. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Air France-KLM (AF FP) – French government announced a EUR 7bln aid package for the Co. which will include EUR 4bln in loan guarantees and EUR 3bln of direct loans. French Finance Minister Le Maire said the government is not currently considering nationalising the Co. Separately, CEO stated that the group may have to wait two years, possibly longer, to return to normal. (Newswires)

Icade (ICAD FP) – Q1 revenue EUR 271.9mln vs. Prev. EUR 302.1mln. Backlog +3.7% YY at EUR 1.3bln. Property development revenue -32% YY to EUR 101mln – with over 90% of construction projects paused. Co. keeps FY20 guidance suspended. (Newswires) 

BROKER MOVES

ACCOR (AC FP) DOWNGRADED TO SELL FROM NEUTRAL AT CITIGROUP

PAN EUROPE

Diasorin (DIA IM) – Co. has obtained FDA Emergency Use Authorisation for funding for its COVID-19 serology kit testing in the US. (Newswires)

Solvay (SOLB BB) – Co. has received approval for the use of Prxitane AHC as a COVID-19 disinfectant. (Newswires)

UBI Banca (UBI IM) – Intesa Sanpaolo (ISP IM) CEO has dismissed speculation Credit Agricole’s (ACA FP) potential interest for UBI Banca. Intesa Sanpaolo shareholders are to meet today to approve a new share issue to support the takeover offer for UBI Banca. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

LEONARDO (LDO IM) DOWNGRADED TO EQUAL WEIGHT FROM OVERWEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY

SIGNIFY (LIGHT NA) UPGRADED TO EQUAL WEIGHT FROM UNDERWEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY

SMI                 

Roche (ROG SW) – Co.’s Pharmaceutical Unit CEO stated that the section of the group has been able to maintain a high level of profitability and is now investing savings in new drugs, with solid growth stable-to-slightly higher margins seen over the next 5-yrs. (Newswires)

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

Kuehne & Nagel (KNIN SW) – Q1 net CHF 139mln vs. Prev. CHF 181mln. EBIT CHF 184mln vs. Prev. CHF 242mln. Revenue CHF 4.91bln vs. Prev. CHF 5.2bln. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA

Ericsson (ERICB SS) – Co. has been selected by True Thailand to run its 5G. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SANDVIK (SAND SS) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM NEUTRAL AT JPMORGAN CHASE

TOPDANMARK (TOP DC) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT SEB ENSKILDA

US

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +1.4% at 2837, NDX +1.7% at 8788, DJI +1.1% at 23,775.SECTORS: Information Technology +2.1%, Communications +1.9%, Materials +1.6%, Health Care +1.4%, Consumer Discretionary +1.4%, Financials +1.4%, Consumer Staples +1.1%, Industrials +0.8%, Utilities +0.6%, Real Estate +0.3%, Energy +0.2%.

subject: US Treasury's semi-annual currency manipulation reportedly has been delayed given COVID-19, according to Taiwanese Central Bank sources
analysis_details:
• The Semi-Annual reports are usually released every April and October
  • The October 2019 report was delayed to January amid the US-China trade war

NOTE: In January's report:

  • US Treasury removed China from currency manipulator list in semi-annual report and says China made enforceable commitments to refrain from competitive devaluation in Phase 1 deal
  • Currency practices of 10 countries require close attention, although no major US trading partner met criteria to be designated a currency manipulator.
  • Continuing to monitor China, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Singapore, Vietnam and Switzerland currency practices.
  • China needs to take necessary steps to avoid a persistently weak currency.

subject: Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 27th April 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

·        Asian equity markets were mostly positive with sentiment underpinned by optimism regarding the reopening of global economies

·        US government trial of Gilead's (GILD) Remdesivir is running ahead of schedule and results from the trial could be possible by mid-May

·        UK PM Johnson could announce plans for easing the lockdown as early as this week after returning to Downing Street

·        Italy PM Conte announced the nation is to begin lifting the lockdown from May 4th with retailers set to open on May 18th

·        BoJ kept NIRP at -0.1% and long term JGB yield target at around 0% but pledged to buy unlimited JGBs and increased its purchases of corporate bonds and commercial paper

·        In FX markets, the DXY weakened overnight amid a lack of demand for safe-havens but remained above the 100.00 level

·        Looking ahead, highlights include ECB purchases, US 2 and 5yr supply 

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

US government trial of Gilead's (GILD) Remdesivir is running ahead of schedule and results from the trial could be possible by mid-May, with potential for earlier preliminary results. However, other reports noted that preliminary results from a Remdesivir test by Chinese scientists found it may reduce sperm count in mice. (Newswires)

US is to cap the amount each bank can lend under the coronavirus relief program with the Small Business Administration to impose a maximum amount for individual lenders at 10% of the Paycheck Protection Program and pace the applications filed. (Newswires)

New York Governor Cuomo said the state will follow the CDC’s recommendation to wait until hospitalization rates decline for 14 days before opening up and outlined that phase 1 will involve construction and manufacturing activities which pose low risk, while phase 2 to be based on a business-by-business analysis of how essential it is and the associated risks. Furthermore, Governor Cuomo noted that the number of deaths in the state from coronavirus increased by 367 on Saturday vs. Prev. 437 on Friday, while there were comments from New York City Mayor De Blasio that the city needs USD 7.4bln from the government to offset impact from the outbreak. (Newswires/Fox)

Italy coronavirus cases rose by 2324 to a total of 197,675 and death toll increased by 260 vs. Prev. 415 which was the smallest daily increase since March 14th. In related news, Italy PM Conte announced to begin lifting the lockdown from May 4th in which bars and restaurants will be able to provide home deliveries and retailers are to reopen on May 18th, while he added that it is reasonable to expect schools to remain shut until the end of the school year. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson could ease lockdown restrictions before the May 7 deadline and is expected to announce plans for easing lockdown as early as this week after returning to Downing Street. (Telegraph) UK Foreign Secretary Raab said lockdown restrictions need to be eased carefully, meaning that social distancing will remain for "some time", while there were separate comments from UK Environment, Food and Rural Affairs Minister Eustice that lockdown measures will be reviewed in a couple of weeks and that it is very important not to act too soon. (BBC/Newswires) National Medical Director of NHS England Stephen Powis stated we now have a very definite trend of reduced hospitalizations and that it is highly likely there will be different types of measures combined which will keep transmission rate down. (Newswires)

China said there are no longer any coronavirus patients at hospitals in Wuhan and it was also reported that the Hong Kong government is considering easing social distancing measures. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly positive with sentiment underpinned by optimism regarding the reopening of global economies after some US states began to reopen businesses and with Italy, Spain and France preparing to ease restrictions after recording their lowest death tolls in a month. ASX 200 (+1.5%) was led higher by tech and industrials with sentiment also supported by loosening of lockdown measures after Queensland announced to permit some outings from next Saturday. However, upside was initially restricted by weakness in the largest weighted financials sector after big 4 bank NAB posted a 51% slump in cash profit and unveiled plans for a substantial share placement, while Nikkei 225 (+2.6%) outperformed amid a weaker currency and the BoJ policy announcement where the central bank announced further measures including a shift to unlimited bond buying as widely speculated. Hang Seng (+1.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.7%) were also higher with Hong Kong surging as its government was said to consider easing social distancing controls and the mainland somewhat lagged after weak Chinese Industrial Profits which contracted by almost 35% Y/Y. Finally, 10yr JGBs were initially lower amid the gains in stocks and similar pressure in T-notes, although JGBs prices were later boosted after the BoJ policy announcement in which the central bank also upped its corporate bond and commercial paper purchases with the maximum limits of purchases from a single issuer upped to JPY 500bln and JPY 300bln respectively from JPY 100bln.

PBoC skipped open market operations and are net neutral on the day. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0703 vs. Exp. 7.0687 (Prev. 7.0803) Chinese Industrial Profits (Mar) Y/Y -34.9% (Prev. 5.4%); YTD (Mar) Y/Y -36.7% (Prev. -38.3%). (Newswires)

China began the Standing Committee of the NPC plenary session where they will decide on the date for when the NPC will take place. (Xinhua)

BoJ kept NIRP at -0.1% and long term JGB yield target at around 0% but pledged to buy unlimited JGBs and increased its purchases of corporate bonds and commercial paper. BoJ said it will buy up to JPY 20tln of corporate bonds, as well as relax rules for corporate bonds and commercial paper purchases, while it will expand the type of assets it accepts as collateral for loan programme to tackle coronavirus. Furthermore, BoJ said it won’t hesitate to ease further if required and removed price momentum from its forward guidance in which it stated it expects short and long-term policy rates to remain at current or lower levels. (Newswires)

BoJ’s Outlook Report stated Japan's economy is to remain in a severe situation due to the spread of coronavirus and that uncertainty on Japan's economic outlook is extremely high but noted the economy is likely to improve on pent-up demand once virus effect subsides and that inflation is likely to gradually accelerate as economy improves.

Real GDP   

Fiscal 2019 forecast lowered to between -0.4% and -0.1% from 0.8%. Fiscal 2020 forecast lowered to between -5.0% and -3.0% from 0.8%. Fiscal 2021 forecast revised to between 2.8% and 2.9% from 1.1%. Fiscal 2022 forecast at between 0.8% and 1.6%.

Core CPI

Fiscal 2019 forecast kept at 0.6%. Fiscal 2020 forecast lowered to between -0.3% and -0,7% from 1.0%. Fiscal 2021 forecast lowered to between 0% and 0.7% from 1.4%. Fiscal 2020 forecast at between 0.4% and 1.0%

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson is set to take personal charge of Brexit talks as he returns to work and looks to put pressure o the EU to move red lines on areas such as regulatory alignment and fisheries. (Times)

EY ITEM Club estimates it will 3 years to return to levels pre-coronavirus levels and forecasts half of UK consumer spending this year will be delayed or lost. (Newswires)

Italian Foreign Minister and 5-Star Leader Di Maio clarified that his remarks that Italy must be “pragmatic” in talks referred to discussions with the EU over aid tools and not the ESM, while he stated they continue to see the ESM as an inadequate tool, (Newswires)

S&P affirmed United Kingdom at AA; Outlook Stable and affirmed Italy at BBB; Outlook Negative, while it affirmed Portugal at BBB; Outlook revised to Stable from Positive and affirmed Greece at BB-; Outlook revised to Stable from Positive on adverse effects of COVID-19. Fitch affirmed Netherlands at AAA; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

FX

In FX markets, the DXY weakened overnight amid a lack of demand for safe havens but remained above the 100.00 level as participants also look ahead to this week’s key releases including US GDP, as well as the latest central bank policy meetings from the Fed and ECB. As such, EUR/USD was relatively flat at the 1.0800 handle and near about EUR 1.6bln of option expiries set to roll off at today’s New York cut, while GBP/USD was firmer and briefly broke above 1.2400 with reports suggesting UK PM Johnson could ease lockdown restrictions before the May 7th deadline. JPY-crosses were mostly higher on the constructive risk tone although USD/JPY was initially flat before slipping lower despite the BoJ’s actions which markets had widely anticipated, while antipodeans were lifted by the risk appetite which helped AUD/USD reclaim the 0.6400 handle and spurred NZD/USD to prod the 0.6050 level despite the absence of participants in New Zealand for ANZAC Day.

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed with oil prices resuming their downturn amid the ongoing demand-related concerns and widespread views the incoming OPEC++ cuts are insufficient in offsetting the demand rout brought on by the coronavirus outbreak. As such, WTI crude futures declined below the USD 16.00/bbl and although there weren’t much fresh catalysts for the energy complex overnight, recent reports had suggested the US Oil Fund could adjust its allocations to increase holdings of later month contracts. Elsewhere, gold prices were subdued by the positive risk tone but with downside stemmed by a weaker greenback, while copper outperformed due to the risk appetite and reopening hopes.

Baker Hughes US Rig Count (w/e Apr. 24th) oil rigs fell by 60 to 378 and nat gas rigs fell by 4 to 85, while total rigs fell by 64 to 465. (Newswires)

US President Trump believes Saudi Arabia and Russia could make further production cuts and believes that will be a natural process now, while he added that Texas, Oklahoma and Canada are cutting production. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said it can be assumed that one option is that the administration is looking at the government taking stakes in energy companies and that several options are being examined, while he added that President Trump also floated the idea of the US government purchasing fuel in the US in advance, as well as airline tickets. (Newswires)

US Oil Fund (USO) may allocate 20% of its portfolio in June contracts (Prev. 20%), 40% in July futures (Prev. 50%), 20% in August (Prev. 20%) and 20% in September (Prev. 10%). (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Japanese media report claimed that North Korea Leader Kim was in a vegetative state following heart surgery. In related news, North Korea state radio issued a statement reportedly from Leader Kim in appreciation of workers furnishing Samjiyon but made no comments on his health or whereabouts. (Yonhap)

Iranian President Rouhani urged the Iranian military to follow strategies ensuring regional stability while keeping vigilance and a strong presence, according to state TV. (Newswires)

US Secretary of State Pompeo is said to prepare a legal argument that the US remains a participant of JCPOA as an effort to pressure Iran and extend arms embargo. (NYT)

Southern Transitional Council separatists which are backed by the United Arab Emirates, scrapped a peace agreement with the Saudi-backed government in Yemen and declared a state of emergency, while the Saudi-led coalition called for an end to any escalation and immediate return to Riyadh agreement. (Newswires)

US

Choppy day for the Treasury complex, albeit in tight ranges with the 10-year yield bouncing between 58/62bps, before moving lower on the updated Fed purchases schedule. As risk appetite rose in the European session, T-Notes and Bunds were offered from their highs overnight. However, after the US cash equity open gains were pared in equities/oil and yields were anchored from rising any further; note that relatively less corporate issuance likely also supported the Treasury curve. Then later, yields broke out of their range to the downside as investors digested the less pronounced cut in Fed asset purchases of USD 10bln/day from 35bln/day (read below). By settlement, 2s unchanged at 0.22, 10s -2bps at 0.59, and 30s -3bps at 1.17%. Meanwhile, Short end rates were supported after the 3-month USD LIBOR posted a chunky 10bps fall, supporting front pack Eurodollars and seeing swap spreads and FRA-OIS tighten. T-notes (M0) settled 3 ticks higher at 139-03+.

Fed plans to purchase USD 50bln in Treasury purchases for the upcoming week from USD 75bln total last week. (Newswires)

White House Adviser Hassett said the US unemployment rate is likely to reach 16% or higher when this month’s jobs report is released. (Newswires)

content: Asia equity markets were mostly positive with sentiment underpinned by optimism regarding the reopening of global economies after some US states began to reopen businesses and with Italy, Spain and France preparing to ease restrictions after recording their lowest death tolls in a month. ASX 200 (+1.5%) was led higher by tech and industrials with sentiment also supported by loosening of lockdown measures after Queensland announced to permit some outings from next Saturday. However, upside was initially restricted by weakness in the largest weighted financials sector after big 4 bank NAB posted a 51% slump in cash profit and unveiled plans for a substantial share placement, while Nikkei 225 (+2.6%) outperformed amid a weaker currency and the BoJ policy announcement where the central bank announced further measures including a shift to unlimited bond buying as widely speculated. Hang Seng (+1.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.7%) were also higher with Hong Kong surging as its government was said to consider easing social distancing controls and the mainland somewhat lagged after weak Chinese Industrial Profits which contracted by almost 35% Y/Y. Finally, 10yr JGBs were initially lower amid the gains in stocks and similar pressure in T-notes, although JGBs prices were later boosted after the BoJ policy announcement in which the central bank also upped its corporate bond and commercial paper purchases with the maximum limits of purchases from a single issuer upped to JPY 500bln and JPY 300bln respectively from JPY 100bln.

subject: BoJ keeps NIRP at -0.1% and long term JGB yield target at around 0% but pledges to buy unlimited JGBs and increases corporate bonds and commercial paper purchases
content:
Says:

  • Removes price momentum from forward guidance in which it states it expects short and long term policy rates to remain at current or lower levels.
  • To buy up to JPY 20tln of corporate bonds and will relax rules for corporate bonds and commercial paper purchases.
  • Increases maximum amount of commercial paper and corporate bonds it buys from single issuer to JPY 500bln and JPY 300bln respectively from JPY 100bln.
  • To expand type of assets it accepts as collateral for loan programme to tackle coronavirus.
  • Will include state affiliated financial institutions as eligible entity for loan programme aimed at tackling coronavirus.
  • Will closely watch COVID-19 and wont hesitate to ease further if required.
  • Will consider new fund supply means for financial institutions.
  • Decision on YCC was 8-1 with Kataoka the dissenter.

 

Outlook Report

  • Japan's economy to remain in severe situation due to spread of coronavirus.
  • Uncertainty on Japan's economic outlook is extremely high.
  • Inflation is likely to gradually accelerate as economy improves.
  • Economy is likely to improve on pent-up demand once virus effect subsides.

 

Real GDP

  • Fiscal 2019 forecast lowered to between -0.4% and -0.1% from 0.8%.
  • Fiscal 2020 forecast lowered to between -5.0% and -3.0% from 0.8%.
  • Fiscal 2021 forecast revised to between 2.8% and 2.9% from 1.1%.
  • Fiscal 2022 forecast at between 0.8% and 1.6%.

 

Core CPI

  • Fiscal 2019 forecast kept at 0.6%.
  • Fiscal 2020 forecast lowered to between -0.3% and -0,7% from 1.0%.
  • Fiscal 2021 forecast lowered to between 0% and 0.7% from 1.4%.
  • Fiscal 2020 forecast at between 0.4% and 1.0%

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks gain amid reopening optimism, while focus shifts to looming risk events
content:
Asia equity markets are mostly positive with sentiment underpinned by optimism regarding reopening of global economies after some US states began to reopen businesses and with Italy, Spain and France preparing to ease restrictions after recording their lowest death tolls in a month. ASX 200 (+0.6%) is led higher by tech and industrials with sentiment also supported by loosening of lockdown measures after Queensland announced to permit some outings from next Saturday. However, upside is restricted by weakness in the largest weighted financials sector after a 51% slump in cash profit and plans for a substantial share placement by big 4 bank NAB, while Nikkei 225 (+2.0%) outperforms amid a weaker currency and ahead of the BoJ policy announcement where there is speculation the central bank is to announce further measures and that a shift to unlimited bond buying could be on the cards. Hang Seng (+1.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.8%) are also higher with Hong Kong outperforming as its government is said to consider easing social distancing controls and with the mainland somewhat lagging after weak Chinese Industrial Profits which contracted by almost 35% Y/Y.

In FX markets, the DXY is weaker overnight amid a lack of demand for safe havens but remains above the 100.00 level as participants also look ahead to this week’s key releases including US GDP, as well as the latest central bank policy meetings from the Fed and ECB. As such, EUR/USD is flat at the 1.0800 handle and near around EUR 1.6bln of option expiries set to roll off at today’s New York cut, while GBP/USD is firmer and briefly broke above 1.2400 with reports suggesting UK PM Johnson could ease lockdown restrictions before May 7th deadline. JPY-crosses are mostly higher on the constructive risk tone although USD/JPY is flat as weakness in safe havens offset each other, while antipodeans are also lifted by the risk appetite which helped AUD/USD reclaim the 0.6400 handle and momentarily pushed NZD/USD above 0.6050 despite the absence of participants in New Zealand for ANZAC Day.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower amid the gains in stocks and pressure in T-notes but with losses stemmed as prices find a base near 152.50 and ahead of the BoJ policy announcement.

subject: PREVIEW: BoJ Policy Decision due today where there is speculation it will consider unlimited bond purchases
analysis_details:
OVERVIEW

The Bank of Japan is to conduct a policy meeting today in which the central bank is expected to maintain its QQE with Yield Curve Control and negative rates at -0.10%, although source reports noted the BoJ is to consider a shift to unlimited bond buying from the current JPY 80tln target and may double purchases of corporate bonds as well as commercial paper. The central bank will also provide its latest Outlook Report which will include board members median forecasts for Real GDP and Core CPI.

 

RECENT ACTIONS & COMMENTS

The BoJ had only announced additional measures at its emergency meeting last month in which it raised purchases of ETFs to JPY 12tln from JPY 6tln and J-REITS to JPY 180bln from JPY 90bln. The central bank also decided to set aside JPY 2tln for more buying of commercial paper and corporate bonds. Since then, BoJ Governor Kuroda has reiterated on several occasions that they will ease without hesitation if necessary and noted they need to support households and firms now so that the economy can stage a V-shaped  recovery when the virus is contained, while he also suggested it is possible to further deepen negative rates and boost JGB purchases.

The coronavirus pandemic has also prompted a firm response from the Japanese government which has approved a total of JPY 117.1tln to cushion the impact to the economy and which includes JPY 100k of handouts to all individuals regardless of income which was a shift from initial plans of JPY 300k to every household that suffered a sharp decline in income from the coronavirus outbreak.

 

SOFTENING ECONOMY

Expectations for further measures have also been supported by the continued deterioration in the economy amid the coronavirus pandemic that has forced Japan to declare a nationwide state of emergency which is currently in place till May 6th. This fallout is evident in the latest trade figures that showed Exports (Mar) Y/Y at -11.7% vs. Exp. -10.1% (Prev. -1.0%) which is the largest decline since 2016, and the latest Tankan survey printed the lowest reading for the Large Manufacturing Index in 7 years of -8, while inflation remains subdued with Core CPI in March softening to 0.4% from 0.6%. In addition, the Japanese government recently cut its economic assessment of the economy amid the pandemic in which it stated the economy is "worsening rapidly" and is in an "extremely severe" situation with the bleakest assessment in 11 years.

 

OUTLOOK REPORT

The BoJ are also set to release its latest Outlook Report which will include the latest inflation and economic growth forecasts by its policy setters and reports had recently noted that board members were considering lowering economic and price outlooks. However, downward revisions to projections wouldn’t be much of surprise given the current gloomy backdrop and current expectations for sharp contractions to economies worldwide from the coronavirus related disruptions.

Previous Forecasts

Real GDP

  • Fiscal 2019 forecast at 0.8%.
  • Fiscal 2020 forecast at 0.8%.
  • Fiscal 2021 forecast at 1.1%.

 

Core CPI

  • Fiscal 2019 forecast at 0.6%.
  • Fiscal 2020 forecast at 1.0%.
  • Fiscal 2021 forecast at 1.4%.

 

ANNOUNCEMENT

There is no exact scheduled time for today’s announcement although the meeting the will begin at 0900 local time (0100BST) which the BoJ hopes to conclude at noon (0400BST). Today’s meeting was also shortened from the central bank’s usual 2-day affair with the change aimed at preventing the spread of coronavirus, while focus will be on whether the central bank announces new measures such as unlimited bond buying which could underpin 10yr JGBs and USD/JPY.
